page.title: Basic, Single-Clause Sentences - Auxiliaries
page.introduction: Some languages have auxiliary elements that are separate words, and some can have more than one auxiliary element before the main verb. Examples are given for English transitive single-clause sentences.

EnglishExample.exItem: The boy will hit the ball.
The boy might have hit the ball.
The boy might have been hitting the ball.

form.introduction: In some languages verbal negation is an auxiliary element, while in others it is simply a verbal affix. English has both the negative auxiliary not, which is a separate word that must always follow another auxiliary, and the contraction form -n’t, which is written as a suffix on the auxiliary. Examples are given for English negative transitive single-clause sentences.

EnglishExample.exItem: The boy did not hit the ball.
The boy didn’t hit the ball.
The boy will not hit the ball.
The boy won’t hit the ball.
The boy might not have hit the ball.

Does your language have one or more negative affixes which attach to a verb to make it negative?
Is there required to be another auxiliary element in the sentence when the negative auxiliary word is present?
radioGroup.radio: No, the negative auxiliary may be the only auxiliary in the phrase
Yes, another auxiliary is required, as in English

form.introduction: The nonfinite word to used in English embedded clauses also acts as an auxiliary in that it fills the same position and can occur before other auxiliaries:

EnglishExample.exItem: The boy wanted to hit the ball.
The boy would like to have hit the ball.
The boy would like to have been running the bases.

form.instruction: Add the features negative makeAux to the negative auxiliary elements that are written as separate words. This will mark them as negative and also assure that they have the category Aux.
Add the feature negative to the negative auxiliary affix(es).
Add the feature negative to the negative verbal affix(es).

Add the feature -finite to the entry for the nonfinite marker that is written as a separate word like to in English and make sure that it is included in the category mapping to Aux in the
Basic, Single-Clause Sentences - Category Mapper. Alternatively, you can add the feature makeAux now to be sure. However, remember that if the word can also be used as another syntactic category (like English to can be both a nonfinite Aux and a preposition P), you need to make a separate lexical entry for each use.
